questions.text: Which of the following is most commonly seen on HRCT in COVID-19 pneumonia
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most commonly seen HRCT finding in COVID pneumonia is Ground glass opacities

  • Several chest CT findings have been reported in more than 70% of RT-PCR test-proven COVID-19 cases, including ground-glass opacities, vascular enlargement, bilateral abnormalities, lower lobe involvement, and posterior predilection.
  • In COVID-19 endemic regions, the observation of these chest CT findings should raise the suspicion of possible COVID-19 diagnosis
  • HRCT is routinely performed in COVID-19 pneumonia

Ground Glass Opacities

  • Definition: Areas of hazy increased lung opacity, with preserved bronchial and vascular markings.
  • Seen in: Early and progressive phases of COVID-19 pneumonia.
  • Distribution:
    • Bilateral
    • Peripheral
    • Posterior
    • Often multilobar (especially lower lobes)
  • GGOs are the hallmark of viral pneumonitis, including COVID-19.

Explanation of Other Options:

Consolidation (Option A):

  • Represents alveolar space filled with fluid, cells, or debris.
  • Less common in early COVID-19.
  • More common in later stages or secondary bacterial infection.
  • Appears as dense, white areas with loss of vessel/airway markings.

Pleural Effusion (Option C):

  • Rare in COVID-19 (~<5% of cases).
  • When present, often indicates:
    • Severe disease
    • Superimposed bacterial infection
    • Cardiac or renal complications

Pericardial Effusion ( Option D):

  • Also rare in COVID-19.
  • May appear in severe or critically ill patients, possibly due to viral pericarditis or generalized inflammation.
